pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 118, 379, 144]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 170, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 194, 332, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice (Core)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 170, 905, 186]]<|/det|>
0625/11  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 194, 905, 210]]<|/det|>
May/June 2022  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[814, 217, 905, 232]]<|/det|>
45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 247, 507, 264]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 277, 437, 285]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 286, 539, 317]]<|/det|>
Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 336, 228, 352]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 354, 112, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>?</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[129, 354, 601, 370]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 369, 907, 400]]<|/det|>
For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 400, 578, 415]]<|/det|>
Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 416, 277, 431]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 431, 868, 462]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 462, 327, 476]]<|/det|>
Do not use correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 477, 364, 492]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 493, 329, 507]]<|/det|>
You may use a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 507, 670, 523]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 550, 220, 564]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 566, 540, 616]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 40. Each correct answer will score one mark. Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A lump of modelling clay is moved from a small measuring cylinder to a large measuring cylinder that has twice the diameter.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 109, 720, 359]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 370, 670, 390]]<|/det|>
The reading on the small measuring cylinder goes down by \(20 \text{cm}^3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 400, 608, 420]]<|/det|>
By how much does the reading on the large cylinder go up?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 428, 134, 446]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 428, 210, 446]]<|/det|>
10 cm³

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[287, 428, 306, 446]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[320, 428, 376, 446]]<|/det|>
20 cm³

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 428, 470, 446]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 428, 544, 446]]<|/det|>
40 cm³

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[613, 428, 635, 446]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 428, 715, 446]]<|/det|>
80 cm³

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 473, 96, 492]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 473, 470, 492]]<|/det|>
The speed–time graph for a train is shown.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 500, 803, 695]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 712, 537, 732]]<|/det|>
Which regions of the graph show the train moving?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 740, 134, 759]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 740, 272, 759]]<|/det|>
P, Q, R and S

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 768, 134, 785]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 768, 287, 785]]<|/det|>
Q, R and S only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 794, 133, 812]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 794, 264, 812]]<|/det|>
Q and S only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 821, 136, 838]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 821, 208, 838]]<|/det|>
R only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 421, 88]]<|/det|> A man stands next to a railway track. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 97, 878, 149]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 171, 571, 189]]<|/det|> A train travelling at \(40 \text{m / s}\) takes 2.0 s to pass the man. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 203, 371, 220]]<|/det|> What is the length of the train? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 231, 134, 249]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 231, 196, 249]]<|/det|> 20 m <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 231, 311, 249]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[320, 231, 361, 249]]<|/det|> 38 m <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 231, 476, 249]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 231, 530, 249]]<|/det|> 40 m <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[613, 231, 641, 249]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 231, 695, 249]]<|/det|> 80 m <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 277, 96, 295]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 277, 920, 310]]<|/det|> A spring balance operates by the compression of a spring. It has been calibrated on the Earth in grams. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 322, 920, 355]]<|/det|> A beam balance operates by balancing standard masses against the unknown mass to be measured. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 367, 845, 384]]<|/det|> The same unknown mass is measured with each balance on the Earth and on the Moon. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 396, 747, 415]]<|/det|> The gravitational field strength on the Earth is greater than that on the Moon. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 427, 759, 444]]<|/det|> How would the measurements on the Earth compare with those on the Moon? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 456, 828, 586]]<|/det|>
spring balance measurementsbeam balance measurements
Alarger on the Earth than on the Moonlarger on the Earth than on the Moon
Blarger on the Earth than on the Moonsame on the Earth as on the Moon
Csame on the Earth as on the Moonlarger on the Earth than on the Moon
Dsame on the Earth as on the Moonsame on the Earth as on the Moon

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 515, 89]]<|/det|>
A measuring cylinder contains \(30 \text{cm}^3\) of a liquid.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[361, 100, 630, 345]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 355, 764, 373]]<|/det|>
Some more of the liquid is added until the liquid level reaches the \(50 \text{cm}^3\) mark.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 386, 499, 403]]<|/det|>
The reading on the balance increases by \(30 \text{g}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 416, 386, 434]]<|/det|>
What is the density of the liquid?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 444, 133, 463]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 444, 744, 463]]<|/det|>
0.60 g/ cm³ B 0.67 g/ cm³ C 1.5 g/ cm³ D 1.7 g/ cm³

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 489, 96, 507]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 489, 920, 523]]<|/det|>
Which pieces of apparatus are the most appropriate for an experiment to plot an extension–load graph of a spring?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 534, 133, 552]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 534, 462, 552]]<|/det|>
ruler, newton meter, clamp and stand

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 560, 133, 579]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 560, 368, 579]]<|/det|>
balance, stop-watch, ruler

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 587, 133, 605]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 587, 400, 605]]<|/det|>
light gate, ruler, newton meter

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 613, 133, 631]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 613, 487, 631]]<|/det|>
stop-watch, balance, measuring cylinder

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 453, 90]]<|/det|>
A beam is pivoted at one end, as shown.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 98, 714, 207]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 218, 745, 238]]<|/det|>
The beam weighs 6.0 N and its weight acts at a point X 40 cm from the pivot.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 250, 710, 268]]<|/det|>
A force of 4.0 N is applied to the beam causing it to balance horizontally.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 280, 574, 298]]<|/det|>
In which direction and where is the 4.0 N force applied?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 308, 133, 327]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 308, 520, 327]]<|/det|>
vertically downwards at 20 cm to the left of X

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 335, 133, 353]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 335, 531, 353]]<|/det|>
vertically downwards at 20 cm to the right of X

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 361, 133, 380]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 361, 500, 380]]<|/det|>
vertically upwards at 20 cm to the left of X

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 388, 133, 406]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 388, 510, 406]]<|/det|>
vertically upwards at 20 cm to the right of X

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 431, 96, 448]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 431, 620, 450]]<|/det|>
The diagrams show the forces acting on four moving objects.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 462, 487, 481]]<|/det|>
Which object is moving at a constant speed?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 488, 831, 696]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 433, 89]]<|/det|>
A mass hangs vertically from a spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 551, 120]]<|/det|>
The mass is raised to a point P and is then released.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 131, 683, 150]]<|/det|>
The mass oscillates repeatedly between point P and a lower point Q.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 161, 763, 180]]<|/det|>
Which energies alternately increase and decrease throughout the oscillations?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 190, 134, 208]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 190, 673, 208]]<|/det|>
gravitational potential energy, kinetic energy and elastic energy

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 216, 133, 234]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 216, 589, 234]]<|/det|>
gravitational potential energy and kinetic energy only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 242, 133, 261]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 242, 680, 261]]<|/det|>
gravitational potential energy, kinetic energy and internal energy

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 268, 133, 286]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 268, 435, 286]]<|/det|>
internal energy and elastic energy

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 312, 106, 331]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 312, 855, 331]]<|/det|>
A force \(F\) acts on an object and the object moves a distance \(d\) in the direction of the force.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 342, 425, 361]]<|/det|>
What is the work done on the object?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 371, 134, 390]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 371, 171, 390]]<|/det|>
\(\frac{F}{d}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 371, 298, 390]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 371, 343, 390]]<|/det|>
\(\frac{d}{F}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 371, 468, 390]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 371, 534, 390]]<|/det|>
\(F\times d\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 370, 636, 390]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[650, 369, 720, 400]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{1}{(F\times d)}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 434, 104, 453]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 434, 569, 453]]<|/det|>
Liquid of mass \(92 \text{kg}\) is contained in a rectangular tank.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 464, 472, 483]]<|/det|>
The area of the base of the tank is \(0.23 \text{m}^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 494, 665, 514]]<|/det|>
What is the pressure exerted by the liquid on the base of the tank?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 523, 134, 541]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 523, 285, 541]]<|/det|>
\(2.5 \times 10^{- 4} \text{N} / \text{m}^2\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 551, 133, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 551, 285, 570]]<|/det|>
\(2.5 \times 10^{- 3} \text{N} / \text{m}^2\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 579, 133, 597]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 579, 237, 597]]<|/det|>
400N/m2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 606, 133, 624]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 606, 247, 624]]<|/det|>
4000N/m2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 109, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 72, 569, 91]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a deep reservoir formed by a dam.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 100, 725, 247]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 259, 457, 278]]<|/det|>
On what does the pressure at X depend?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 287, 138, 306]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 287, 373, 306]]<|/det|>
the depth of the water at X

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 314, 134, 332]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 314, 366, 332]]<|/det|>
the length of the reservoir

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 341, 134, 358]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 341, 390, 358]]<|/det|>
the surface area of the water

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 365, 134, 384]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 365, 393, 384]]<|/det|>
the thickness of the dam wall

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 411, 109, 428]]<|/det|>
<label>13</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 410, 593, 428]]<|/det|>
The list gives three properties of different states of matter.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 440, 567, 459]]<|/det|>
1 They cannot be compressed significantly.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 466, 346, 485]]<|/det|>
2 They can flow.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 492, 574, 511]]<|/det|>
3 They always completely fill their container.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 522, 448, 541]]<|/det|>
Which properties are correct for liquids?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 551, 133, 568]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 551, 740, 568]]<|/det|>
1 and 2 only B 2 and 3 only C 1 and 3 only D 1, 2 and 3

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 596, 107, 613]]<|/det|>
<label>14</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 594, 724, 613]]<|/det|>
Two thermometers, P and Q, give the same reading at room temperature.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 625, 920, 658]]<|/det|>
The bulb of thermometer Q is wrapped in gauze and dipped in a beaker of water at room temperature.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 670, 658, 689]]<|/det|>
Air at room temperature is blown over the two thermometer bulbs.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 701, 658, 720]]<|/det|>
Which statement correctly describes and explains what happens?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 730, 133, 747]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 730, 707, 747]]<|/det|>
P reads higher than Q because bulb P absorbs energy from the air.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 756, 133, 774]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 756, 836, 774]]<|/det|>
P reads higher than Q because water evaporates from the gauze and cools bulb Q.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 782, 133, 801]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 782, 668, 801]]<|/det|>
P reads lower than Q because the wet gauze insulates bulb Q.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 808, 133, 826]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 808, 841, 826]]<|/det|>
P reads lower than Q because water evaporates from the gauze and warms bulb Q.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 109, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|> What happens to the volumes of liquid metal and of solid metal when heated at constant pressure? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 116, 505, 261]]<|/det|>
volume of liquid metalvolume of solid metal
Adecreasesincreases
Bdecreasesno change
Cincreasesincreases
Dincreasesno change
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 288, 106, 306]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 288, 531, 307]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a liquid-in-glass thermometer. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 314, 767, 357]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 371, 803, 390]]<|/det|> A student wishes to check the marking of the upper fixed point on this thermometer. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 401, 295, 420]]<|/det|> What should she do? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 431, 134, 448]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 431, 520, 448]]<|/det|> Put the bulb in a beaker of boiling sea water. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 457, 133, 475]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 457, 527, 475]]<|/det|> Put the bulb in a beaker of boiling pure water. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 483, 131, 502]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 483, 475, 500]]<|/det|> Put the bulb in a beaker of ice and salt. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 509, 133, 527]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 509, 512, 527]]<|/det|> Put the bulb in a beaker of pure melting ice. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 553, 104, 571]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 553, 922, 587]]<|/det|> A glass contains an iced drink on a warm and humid day. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 212, 379, 231]]<|/det|>

1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 241, 215, 259]]<|/det|>
and

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 286, 710, 304]]<|/det|>
A model of an atom consists of small particles orbiting a central nucleus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 317, 455, 336]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 345, 134, 364]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 345, 346, 364]]<|/det|>
on the orbiting particles

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 371, 133, 390]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 371, 270, 390]]<|/det|>
in the nucleus

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 397, 131, 416]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 397, 638, 416]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 424, 133, 443]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 424, 384, 443]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 469, 106, 486]]<|/det|>
<label>39</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 467, 510, 486]]<|/det|>
A radioactive source has a half-life of 0.5 hours.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 498, 707, 516]]<|/det|>
A detector near the source shows a reading of 6000 counts per second.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 527, 428, 545]]<|/det|>
Background radiation can be ignored.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 558, 541, 576]]<|/det|>
What is the reading on the detector 1.5 hours later?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 710, 104, 728]]<|/det|>
<label>40</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 710, 707, 727]]<|/det|>
Which statement about the radioactive decay of a substance is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 737, 131, 755]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 737, 640, 755]]<|/det|>
It cannot be predicted when a particular nucleus will decay.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 764, 131, 782]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 764, 824, 782]]<|/det|>
Placing a radioactive substance inside a lead-lined box prevents it from decaying.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 790, 131, 809]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 790, 534, 809]]<|/det|>
The decay always produces poisonous gases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 816, 133, 835]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 816, 695, 835]]<|/det|>
The rate of decay increases if the substance is dissolved in water.
